chapter.header: General Help for the GS Soil Portal

section.header: Concept and tasking of GS Soil Portal

content.p: Co-funded by the community programme eContentplus GS Soil aims at establishing a Best Practice Network dealing with a cluster of the data themes listed in the Annexes I to III of the INSPIRE Directive (2007/2/EC) and focused on soil related issues.

The establishment of the soil thematic strategy and the new transboundary EU approach for protected sites management has enforced the link between soil conservation and best practice use and geo-information. This has generated the need for interoperable, accessible and harmonised datasets for the EU. The link is also addressed by the INSPIRE Directive which pursues an EU Spatial Data Infrastructure to support environmental policies.

The GS Soil Network aims, through state-of-the-art methodologies and best practice examples, to improve harmonisation of national datasets and make them more accessible and exploitable within Europe. Therefore, the consortium contributes to the INSPIRE implementation with specific reference to a cluster of data themes on nature conservation (as per the INSPIRE Annexes). Within the INSPIRE directive the theme soil is explicitly addressed as an individual theme (Annex III) and besides that soil related environmental, agricultural and forestry aspects are also addressed in Annex II and III. According to this, the thematic focus of GS Soil is set on soil as an important parameter according to climate, land use, geology and geomorphology. At the same time soils are the basis for food production and consumer health, for the ecological and economical balance and for many other important bases of life.
Considering the INSPIRE Annexes, the following soil and soil related themes will be considered:

ul.li: Basic soil describing information including depth, texture, structure and organic material as described in Annex III theme "Soil",
Information about soil monitoring facilities and long term observations as part of the Annex III theme "Environmental Monitoring Facilities",

Information about the soil related aspects of Annex III theme "Natural Risk Zones" as e.g. landslides, soil erosion, soil compaction, soil organic carbon decline, salinization, acidification and soil biodiversity loss,
Soil related information of the INSPIRE Annex III theme "Human Health and Safety" and
Soils as primary site factor to identify protected land as part of the INSPIRE Annex I theme "Protected Sites" (e.g. peat land, extrazonal sites)

content.p: As expected result from the project GS Soil the GS Soil Portal was set up. The GS Soil Portal provides access to all project soil data. GS Soil Portal is maintained from technical and contents point of view by Coordination Center PortalU in the Lower Saxony ministry for environment and climate protection in Hanover.

Search: Central function of the Portal is the Search, with the help of which web pages and data base entries can be searched via a customary full text search (Simple search),but can also be searched using a differentiated specialist vocabulary (Advanced Search).
Publication: Here you can find current publications from the soil field.
Maps: A maps viewer offers the possibility of entering spatial references for the search via interactive maps or else to display digitale maps from the search results list directly in GS Soil Portal.
News: Current reports are displayed directly from GS Soil News feed.

section.header: Information sources in GS Soil Portal

content.p: GS Soil Portal is a convenient and user-friendly portal for soil and soil related information in the internet. In contrast to most portals and search engines, GS Soil Portal gathers not only web pages, text documents and other internet formats but can also access databases and specialist information systems, even when these are not online.

section.header: Conditions for the use and participation in GS Soil Portal

content.p: The circle of data providers in GS Soil Portal restricts itself mainly to GS Soil Network in Europe, but is being continually expanded. If your organisation would likewise like to make soil relevant information available, please contact the Coordination Center PortalU.

section.header: InGrid – the software behind GS Soil Portal

content.p: The InGrid software package was developed to realise PortalU the central environmental Information portal for Germany. InGrid is positioned on modular and flexible system architecture based on licence-free open source products. This way it becomes possible to adapt the technical structure of the environment information net to changing organisational specifications. Thus, if needed, regional environment portals, e.g. for individual German Federal States or Local Authorities can be created with minimal technical expense. Thanks to OpenSource the follow up use of the software is license free and free of cost for partners of the VwV UDK/GEIN.

section.header: Quick Start guide to the search

content.p: Via the GS Soil Portal you can search for different types of data sources:
For a quick overview about the different data, please enter for
as search query. With those queries you receive all entries from those three data types.
If you want to specify your search query, please use the different options of the Advanced search.
When you use the search function you can enter one or more search terms. Those pages that contain all search terms will be found.
In addition to the simple search you can further refine your search. Read the following topics on this:
You can refine your search for soil information via the Advanced Search option.

In principle, a search term is composed from individual search terms, which are connected by the operators (AND, OR, NOT). You can read about how you can enter these operators manually in the chapter Expert entry .
The Advanced Search offers you the possibility of constructing your search term using a wizard.
The so-called search area embraces all web pages, documents etc. which are captured by a search query. The following areas are available to you to expand or restrict the search area:
In this area you can add well directed one or several search terms to your search term by linking it with one of the following options:
all search terms (AND): a piece of information will be found if it contains all the terms entered (standard).
one of the search terms (OR): a piece of information will be found if it contains at least one of the terms entered.
the exact search string: a piece of information will be found if it contains exactly the word group entered (in the same sequence, with spaces etc.).
none of the search terms (NOT): a piece of information will only be found if it contains none of the terms entered.
You can add specialist terms to your search term via the specialist dictionary. To do this you put any term into the entry field and send a query to the Thesaurus.
You will then receive a series of similar terms,which you can add to the search term. You can further specify your search term by clicking on a similar term.

Like a dictionary, a thesaurus consists of specialist terms on a certain subject area. In addition to the correct spelling, a thesaurus also contains information whether and how a term can be generalised (superordinate terms), specialised (subordinate terms) or expressed in another way (synonyms). Thesauri are used, for example, for indexing keywords and finding documents.

GS Soil Portal uses the GEneral Multilingual Environmental Thesaurus (GEMET). GEMET is a thesaurus for the classification of environmental resources that has been developed by the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the European Topic Centre on Catalogue of Data Sources (ETCCDS) together with international experts. It contains 6.562 terms which have been arranged in a classification scheme and the terms have been translated into 31 languages.

After your search terms are analysed by the semantic service, similar terms are displayed from the thesaurus. You can highlight one or more of these terms and adopt them in your search term (Add to Query).

However, you also have the possibility of further specifying a similar term by clicking on the respective term. It will then be shown as a thesaurus keyword. In addition, the associated superordinate, subordinate and related terms will be displayed as well as the synonyms.
This is the thesaurus keyword currently set. You can adopt it into your search term by crossing it and clicking on the Add to Query button
A superordinate term is a term that generalises a thesaurus keyword. GEMET provides the possibility of a thesaurus term having several superordinate terms.
You can add the superordinate term(s) to your search term by crossing it and clicking on the Add to Query button.
A subordinate term is a term that makes a thesaurus keyword more specific. A thesaurus term can possess as many subordinate terms as desired.
You can add one or more subordinate terms to your search term by crossing them and clicking on Add to Query button.
A related term is a thesaurus term that is connected with the thesaurus keyword, but is neither a super nor a subordinate term. A thesaurus term can possess any number of related terms.
You can add one or more related terms to your search term by crossing them and clicking on the Add to Query.
A synonym is an alternative expression, but one with the same meaning for the thesaurus keyword.

Sometimes a synonym consists of two or several thesaurus terms. In this case, the synonym is not to be understood as an alternative expression for a single thesaurus term but as a synonym for the combined term.
You can add one or more synonyms to your search term by crossing them and clicking Add to Query button.
If you click on the synonym term then you will reach the thesaurus terms behind. You can also adopt these in your search expresssion.

Via the gazetteer GS Soil Portal analyses for every web page, which is made available by GS Soil Portal, the according spatial reference. This spatial reference is used in GS Soil Portal whithin the framework of the area search. Therefore, the area search is not, as in most other search engines, a full text search for spatial terms.
In the connected databasees the area search takes place by browsing the area attributes entered there.

You can add geographical terms in a targeted way to your search term via conceptual area restriction. To do this you enter any term into the entry field and send a query to the Gazetteer (Button Look up Geographic Names). Thereby a query to the gazetteer is started.

Then you receive a listing of geographical names, which you can add to the search term. If you want further to specify your search term, just click one of the geographic names in the result list. Now a list appears with further geographic names which feature a position relation to the originally search result.

Just like the place index of an atlas, the gazetteer depicts the names of communities, rivers, mountains, landscapes and other geographical objects in Europe. In so doing, the gazetteer gives the exact spelling as well as the geographical position (coordinates) of a place.
The gazetteer is made available via the semantic service integrated in the GS Soil Portal.

The search term that you have sent off via the Search geographical names button is analysed by the semantic service and you receive a series of geographical names by return. You can now add a cross to these and add them to your search term. The geographical names are used to search for an area in the area information of the web pages and the data bases.
If you want to further refine your area search terms then you can look at the positional relationships by clicking once on the respective term.

After clicking on a geographical name, the positional relationships to this name are displayed. The positional relationships are a measure for the spatial relevance between two geographical objects. By selecting (clicking on) positionally relevant geographical names you can further concretise the spatial reference desired.

The GS Soil search can be restricted as to area not only via terms but also by selecting a map section (bounding box). When you have defined a suitable bounding box, a targeted search runs over the web provision made available via GS Soil Portal for area terms (such as, for example, towns, mountains etc.) that are found in the map section. In the databases available via GS Soil Portal, the map section (search rectangle) is searched for directly.
For orientation and specifiation of a map section you can use the background maps service (Web Map Service) of GS Soil Portal or use external map services.

In the GS Soil map viewer map services, legends and metadata search are sorted in different tabs, which are situated to the left of the map. By clicking on a tab the respective menu item will be opened.

In the GS Soil map viewer map services, legends, metadata search and WFS download are sorted in different tabs, which are situated to the left of the map. By clicking on a tab the respective menu item will be opened.

In the menu item Legend all available legends of the map layers are depicted, which are activated under Active Services and are depicted as maps in the viewer. The legend gives information about which symbols and/or colours are used to display the different information in the map.
All map services found under Active Services can be activated or de-activated by one click in map viewer. The map services with their layers are depicted in a tree structure.
The single symbols have the following meaning:

Moves the section up: A highlighted service and/or a highlighted layer is pushed upwards by one level. A service or layer can be highlighted by clicking with the left mouse button on the name. For depiction in the map the following applies: layers, which are listed further down in the tree structure, overlie layers that are listed further at the top.

Moves the section down: A highlighted service and/or a highlighted layer is displaced downwards by one level. A service or a layer can be highlighted by clicking with the left mouse button on the name. If one layer is overlaid by another one then this can be rendered visible by displacing downwards. The layer, which is at the bottom end of the list, is always depicted as the uppermost layer in the map.

Remove the selected WMS: A highlighted service is deleted from the Active Services area. A service can be highlighted by clicking with the left mouse button on the name. It is not possible to remove individual layers.

Active services: The folder symbol is used to display the map services. The corresponding layers of a service are to be found in the individual folders. You can drag, remove the service or alter its transparency with one click (left mouse button) on the folder symbol.
This symbol is used to display one layer. You can drag the service, zoom onto the layer of the service or call up information with one click (left mouse key) on the symbol.

Toggles the visibility of the service: If the check box for a service or a layer is ticked then the service or layer in the map is activated and shown in the map if the corresponding degree of zoom (pre-defined standard for the layer) is set. Furthermore corresponding layer information can be summoned up in the map via the Query (toolbar) button If the map section represented is outside the zoom level of the layer then the layer in the map is not displayed and the layer title is represented in grey. If a service is ticked then all the layers of the service are activated. If the tick is removed from a service then all the layers of the service are de-activated.

Show metadata: Further information (metadata) about a service and/or a layer is displayed for Web Map Services. The information, which originate from the particular GetCapabilities-URL, are readout from the data base of map viewer. If in the GetCapabilities-URL specific data as e.g. to the organisation or address are lacking, some fields can not be filled.
Under topics you will find different map services from data provider sorted according to soil topics and which can be loaded into the map viewer.
The single symbols have the following meaning:
The folder symbol is used for displaying different soil topics. In the folder you find the corresponding map services.

Add WMS to the active services and zoom in: With one click (left mouse button) on this symbol the corresponding service is added to the active services and, in the map, the map section described by the service is zoomed in. Here the following also applies: if the service contains less than 11 layers, all layers will be also activated directly in the map. If the service contains more than 10 layers, the layers are not automatically activated to keep the load time low.

Show metadata: Further information (metadata) about a service and/or a layer is displayed for Web Map Services. The information, which originate from the particular GetCapabilities-URL, are readout from the data base of map viewer. If in the GetCapabilities-URL specific data as e.g. to the organisation or address are lacking, some fields can not be filled.

By means of this button a PDF-document of the map is produced with or without a key. You can select the orientation of the map and in addition insert a title and commentary. You can print or save the document via the usual PDF functions.

GS Soil Portal is able to search for the time references of the connected systems. For this, on the one hand, the data are used that the semantic service has analysed from the web pages as time references. On the other hand, the time references in the databases are accessed.

As a time reference you can either give a time frame (From/To) or a point in time (On the). In both cases the format for giving the date is DD.MM.YYYY, that is two figures for the Day, two for the Month and four for the Year.

Basically all pieces of information are always found if their time reference is within the search intervals you have entered. By crossing boxes you can also find information to which the following apply:

ul.li: The time reference of the results intersects the search interval entered.
The time reference of the results encloses the search interval entered.

content.p: Here you can ascertain whether you want to search through all soil information or whether you would only like to search in publications.

In addition to web servers, metadatasystems and specialist data systems are also connected to GS Soil Portal. You can choose whether you want to search in all these systems (default), or whether you would like to restrict your search in a targeted manner to one or several kinds of data sources.
If you limit your search to metadata then you also have the possibility of selecting the classes of metadata that you would like to search. The following classes are available to you:

The data provided in GS Soil Portal come from the data provider out of the GS Soil network. You can limit the information provided for your search to selected countries. It is also possible to choose several items.
The different data provider belonging to a country are displayed if you click on the plus sign . It is also possible to choose several items.

GS Soil Portal stores a history of your search queries. As well as this history, which is automatically carried for one session, you can also as a logged in user (see myGS Soil) save search queries permanently.
You can call up both forms of stored search queries again via the History function.
In this area your last search queries submitted are listed. By clicking on a search query this is then loaded in the search window and the search is carried out.

In this area your permanently saved search queries will be listed. By clicking on a search query this is then loaded into the search window and the search is carried out. Saved search queries can be removed by putting a cross and then using the delete button.
You can control the display of search results under the Options heading.
You can have your search results displayed either according to ranking (relevance of the page found to your search term) or according to newness (the newest pages will be at the top).
Grouping means that the search results are displayed compiled according to coubtries, data providers or domains.

GS Soil Portal not only carries out the usual indexing found in search engines but also has the page contents analysed by the semantic service. As a result of this analysis specialist terms from the thesaurus are assigned to the web pages.

If you chose to include the setting Include similar terms in search by putting a cross, the associated similar terms will be taken into account. (Note: In most cases the number of hits will be increased by selecting this setting.)

section.header: You would also like to include similar terms in the search?

content.p: You have three possibilities for including similar terms in the search:

ul.li: Automatically: in the settings for the search Options form cross the option Include similar terms in the search. You can also use these setting on a lasting basis (see myGS Soil).
Before conducting a search expand your search term with similar terms by using the Topic/Thesaurus functionality of the Advanced Search.
After a search you will be offered Similar Terms next to the search results list, by means of which you can expand your search term.

section.header: You would like to limit your search to information about the place you live in?

content.p: For this use Search Area. You can either call up a search rectangle over the search area desired (By Map) or enter your town (By geograhic Name).

section.header: You are only interested in information about your country?

content.p: You can select your country via the Search Area of the search.
You can also have these settings on a lasting basis (see myGS Soil).

section.header: You have a particular search query that you can't formulate via the advanced search?

content.p: GS Soil Portal allows complex search queries to be carried out that go beyond the possibilities of the advanced search (e.g. grouping via bracketing or similarity search etc.). For this read section Expert search in GS Soil Portal help and put your search term into the search field.
After carrying out a search query the users logged in have the possibility of saving the search term used on a long-term basis (see myGS Soil) This takes place via the Save Query function.
Note: The search queries last used are also accessible without saving for the session in progress via Search History.

All settings of the advanced search and some further additional special settings can also be entered directly into the search via the search string. As the syntax is very extensive because of the great number of search methods, it is meant for experts in particular.
The individual search terms can be linked via Boolean operators. The following operators are available:

AND: All the words have to be in the document. It is the standard if no operator is given. (Note: instead of AND the symbol && verwendet werden)
For example: ‚water fish’ equates to ‚water AND fish’ or ‚water && fish’

OR: One of the words has to be in the document. (Note: instead of OR the symbol || can be used)
Example: ‚water OR fish’ equates to ‚water || fish’

NOT: : The word after NOT must not be in the document. (Hint: instead of NOT the symbol ! or the symbol | - can be used)
Example: ‚soil NOT ground’ (the search is for soil but not for ground)
The individual search terms linked by Boolean operators can be optionally grouped by bracketing (round brackets).
Example: ‚fish NOT (trout OR perch)’ (all documents are found that contain the term ‚fish’ but not the terms ‚trout’ and ‚perch’)
If a string is placed in quotation marks (?), then the occurrence of the whole string is sought and not the occurrence of the individual terms.
Example: ‚The fish swims in the water’ (Only texts are found that contain exactly this string.)

Within a search term it is possible to enter wild cards for one (?) or more (*) optional signs. All terms are then found that match the rest of the search term whereby one or more signs can appear for the wild card.
Example: ‚te?t’ (Not only documents with the term‚text’ but also documents with the term ‚test’ will be found)

It is possible to search for areas of symbols. The areas are collected in square [] or curved {} brackets and the bottom and top pieces of information are linked with the operator TO. Square brackets [] signify that the lower and upper value of the area are included in the search. Curved brackets {} signify that the lower and the upper value of the area are not included in the search.
Example: ‚[Aller TO Elbe]’ (Documents are sought that contain words that begin with all in the alphabet and end at Elbe. The words ‚Aller’ ‚Elbe’ are included in the search area by this.
Example: ‚{Aller TO Elbe}’ (Documents are sought that contain words starting alphabetically with Aller and ending at Elbe. The words ‚Aller’ ‚Elbe’ are not contained in the search area in this.
The search area can also be given inside a search word.
Example: ‚te[i TO x]t’ (documents are searched for that contain, for example, the words teilt, test or text).
As an alternative to the operator TO a hyphen ‚-’ can also be used.
Example: ‚te[i - x]t’ (documents are searched for that, for example, contain the words tent, test or text).
Documents are also found via the fuzzy search in which terms with similar spelling are found. The fuzzy search is instigated by attaching a tilde (~) to the search term.
Example: ‚Corn~’ (documents will be found containing the term ‚horn’ for example)
The following characters have a special meaning in the GS Soil search string (e.g. in the form of operators):
Should you however use them as simple symbols within a search term then they must be marked as such by the symbol \ (back slash).
Example: ‚\(1\+1\)\:2’ (The expression ‚(1+1):2’ is sought)
In GS Soil Portal different document types can be searched for. For this the syntax ‚fileformat:value’ is used.
Example: ‚fileformat:pdf’ (only PDF documents are searched for.)
The following values are available for the ‚fileformat’ field in GS Soil Portal:

Only RTF documents are searched for
Only MS Word documents are searched for

Only MS-PowerPoint documents are searched for

content.p: The GS Soil Portal full text index is organized in different fields. All fields used in GS Soil Portal can be searched individually in targeted fashion. For this the syntax ‚field name:value’ is used.
In searching for a data type the field name is ‚datatype’
Example: ‚datatype:metadata’ (documents are searched for that are arranged under metadata)
The following values are available for the ‚datatype’ field in GS Soil Portal:

content.p: The search can be restricted to documents that are associated with a certain spatial reference. The spatial reference can be stated via coordinates or via the area key of the administrative unit.
Example: ‚areaid:2800866’ (The search will be restricted to Berlin as administrative unit.)
Example: ‚x1:3.44 y1:50.27 x2:5.25 y2:51.42’ (The search is restricted to a selected rectangle.)
The following fields are available in GS Soil Portal for the restriction of the spatial reference:
The coordinates have to be entered as degrees (WGS 84).
The search can be restricted to documents that are associated with a particular time reference.
Example: ‚t1:2009-06-01 t2:2010-12-31’ (The search is restricted to a selected time interval.)
The following fields are available in GS Soil Portal for the restriction of the time reference:

The document was associated with a time span that begins with the value stated
The document was associated with a time span that ends with the value stated

content.p: The times stated must always be entered in the form YYYY-MM-DD (Y=year, M=month, D=day).

After submitting a search query you will receive the result list. It is broken down into the main result list (left column) and the list with results from broader data sources (right column). You will also be given the possibility of refining your search query via the Search form and to do another search. For this you can also use the similar terms offered to you.
In the main result list you will be shown the results from the search in the web pages of the connected server as well as in the metadata systems in a list weighted according to relevance.
Instead of the simple weighted list you can also have the results displayed grouped according to different countries or according to data providers or sorted according to their actuality.

If the information you have found is a web page then, as well as a series of pieces of information (e.g. title, description and provider), you will receive a link by means of which you will be led directly to the original page.

If the information you have found is a metadata information you will be led via the link to the detailed representation of the specialist information. In the cases, where there is a direct link available to a web page in which the meta- or specialist information is available, then you will be offered this and will be led by this to the original page. In the cases in which there is a map beyond, you will get a Show map link offered by means of which you can open the map in GS Soil Portal map viewer.

As well as the metadata systems incorporated in the main result list, further information systems are also interrogated via GS Soil Portal. The interfaces of these systems do not allow any integration of the search results into the weighted main results list. The search results are therefore shown in a separate list sorted according to data sources. In doing so the data sources are listed in the order of successful responses logged.
You will be guided further via the links provided either directly to the individual search results or to a search result list in the source system according to the data source.

GS Soil Portal offers you the possibility of expanding your search query by similar terms. For this, the search string entered by you will be analysed by a semantic service integrated in the GS Soil Portal.

If you click on the plus sign you will be offered the similar terms for each search term entered. These can be displayed again with the sign. By putting a cross next to the individual terms and clicking on the Add to search button, the similar terms will be added to the associated search term each time such that a document will be found if either the search term or the similar term are contained (OR linking).

The representation of the body of words in a thesaurus takes place in a tree structure, starting with the top terms of GEMET. When a thesaurus term (descriptor) is selected by clicking on it. In the result list all metadata entries are listed which include the selected thesaurus term as keyword or search term. The list of metadata sets is grouped according to the different metadata catalogues. The detailed representation of a metadata set takes place after a query, i.e. by clicking on its title, just as in the list of the search results in the free search. Switching between soil information and addresses takes place in the area of the result list.
Under ‚Publications’ all press realeases out of the GS Soil network are collected.
From this menu item you reach the corresponding pages of the data providers.
In this area you can select from which country you will search for publications.
You can carry out multiple selections by holding down the ctrl-key and then clicking on the countries desired.
If select all is selected then the information of all data providers is displayed.

You can get the results displayed either according to the selected countries or according to the individual data providers. This means that all information of a country or of a data provider are collected into a group and displayed together.
If you do not wish such a grouping you can select the No setting.

With the GS Soil map viewer you can view diffent maps with soil and soil related informations. Select a map service from the heading Topics or the heading Partner or add an external service. If you have reached map viewer via a search result (Show map), the corresponding map will be displayed to you immediately.

In the GS Soil map viewer map services, legends, metadata search and download service are sorted in different tabs, which are situated to the left of the map. By clicking on a tab the respective menu item will be opened.

In the menu item ‚Legend’ all available legends of the map layers are depicted, which are activated under ‚Active Services’ and are depicted as maps in the viewer. The legend gives information about which symbols and/or colours are used to display the different information in the map.
All map services found under ‚Active Services’ can be activated or de-activated by one click in map viewer. The map services with their layers are depicted in a tree structure.
The single symbols have the following meaning:

Moves the section up: A highlighted service and/or a highlighted layer is pushed upwards by one level. A service or layer can be highlighted by clicking with the left mouse button on the name. For depiction in the map the following applies: layers, which are listed further down in the tree structure, overlie layers that are listed further at the top.

Moves the section down: A highlighted service and/or a highlighted layer is displaced downwards by one level. A service or a layer can be highlighted by clicking with the left mouse button on the name. If one layer is overlaid by another one then this can be rendered visible by displacing downwards. The layer, which is at the bottom end of the list, is always depicted as the uppermost layer in the map.

Remove the selected WMS: A highlighted service is deleted from the ‚Active Services’ area. A service can be highlighted by clicking with the left mouse button on the name. It is not possible to remove individual layers.

Active services: The folder symbol is used to display the map services. The corresponding layers of a service are to be found in the individual folders. You can drag, remove the service or alter its transparency with one click (left mouse button) on the folder symbol.
This symbol is used to display one layer. You can drag the service, zoom onto the layer of the service or call up information with one click (left mouse key) on the symbol.

Toggles the visibility of the service: If the check box for a service or a layer is ticked then the service or layer in the map is activated and shown in the map if the corresponding degree of zoom (pre-defined standard for the layer) is set. Furthermore corresponding layer information can be summoned up in the map via the ‚Query’ (toolbar) button If the map section represented is outside the zoom level of the layer then the layer in the map is not displayed and the layer title is represented in grey. If a service is ticked then all the layers of the service are activated. If the tick is removed from a service then all the layers of the service are de-activated.
Show metadata: Further information (metadata) is displayed about a service.
Under topics you will find different map services from data provider sorted according to soil topics and which can be loaded into the GS Soil map viewer.
The single symbols have the following meaning:
The folder symbol is used for displaying different soil topics. In the folder you find the corresponding map services.

Add WMS to the active services and zoom in: With one click (left mouse button) on this symbol the corresponding service is added to the active services and, in the map, the map section described by the service is zoomed in. Here the following also applies: if the service contains less than 11 layers, all layers will be also activated directly in the map. If the service contains more than 10 layers, the layers are not automatically activated to keep the load time low.
Show metadata: Further information (metadata) is displayed about a service.
Under Partner you will find the map services relevant for soil and soil related information belonging to different data provider out of the GS Soil network and which are sorted by countries
The meaning of the individual symbols are described under the Topics menu item (see above).
In the metadatasearch you can search for map services belonging to Partner, which are integrated in the GS Soil map viewer. For this, enter a search term and click on Ok.
In the search result list the following symbols are used:

Add WMS to the active services: With one click (left mouse button) on this symbol the corresponding service is added to the active services. If the service contains fewer than 11 layers, all layers are directly activated in the map as well. If, however, the service contains more than 10 layers, these are not autmatically activated so as to keep the load time low.

Add WMS to the active services and zoom in: With one click (left mouse button) on this symbol the corresponding service is added to the active services and, in the map, the map section described by the service is zoomed in. Here the following also applies: if the service contains less than 11 layers, all layers will be also activated directly in the map. If the service contains more than 10 layers, the layers are not automatically activated to keep the load time low.
Add layer to the active services: With one click (left mouse button) on this symbol the corresponding layer is added to the active services.

Add layer to the active services and zoom in: With one click (left mouse button) on this symbol, the corresponding layer is added to the active services and the map section described by the service in the map is zoomed in.
With one click on the name of the service or layer further information is displayed about the service or layer.

With help of this tab, data providers out of the GS Soil Network can enter easily new map services via this graphical user interface which will stored directly in the database. After approval by the administrator these services will be available in the map viewer.

The Download Service permits the user to query and download soil datasets from the GS Soil Portal, map viewer component. These datasets are made available by the GS Soil data provider's network that is connected to the portal.

p.b: NOTE: In the current version, no Rights Management component exists; therefore only public soil data is available.

content.p: The sections below aim to help the user to use correctly and efficiently the download service.

p.u: Step 1 : select the download service option from map viewer

content.p: The user should select the ‚Search WFS’ tab. A tree list shall be presented, categorised by country name. When pressing the icon in a tree element, e.g.: near the country name, a list of WFS services (children) shall be displayed. When pressed in the WFS service name, it shall display all available WFS layers (children) of that service.

In the other hand, when the user presses the icon, at any level, country or service, all the children will be made invisible (it will collapse the tree at the selected level, i.e. it will hide the layers or the services).

p.u: Step 2 : select the layers to download data from

content.p: When the user is satisfied with the layer selection from the desired WFS services (e.g.: user may select more than one layer, from the same service or different services of the same or different countries).
Optionally the user can zoom in to the layers map extended by pressing the icon on the left of the layer name. This will centre and display the layer in the map viewer.

Further information (metadata) about a service and/or a layer is displayed for Web Feature Services. The information, which originate from the particular GetCapabilities-URL, are readout from the data base of the map viewer. If in the GetCapabilities-URL specific data as e.g. to the organisation or address are lacking, some fields can not be filled.

p.u: Step 5 : selecting a spatial filter (bounding box rectangle)

content.p: After the selection of the layers the user must now select a spatial filter that shall be applied to the layers. This will limit the amount of soil data that will be retrieved by this operation.

In order to achieve that objective, a button is available in the toolbar above the map, the last button on the right. The user must click on it, to make the tool active and afterwards it should draw over the map a rectangle (called bounding box). Click first and hold the left mouse button on the map (this will set the top left corner of the rectangle) and then drag the mouse to the final location and release the left mouse button (this will set the lower right corner of the rectangle).
To be noted, on the lower part of the map, the coordinates of the select spatial filter bounding box rectangle.

p.u: Step 6 : executing or cancelling the query

content.p: After the spatial filter is set (over the map) the user may select the ’download’ button or the ’new’ button, both present below the tree list of the Search WFS download service tab.

While the last button will cancel the spatial filter - meaning the user should redo the spatial rectangle over the map or eventually cancel the procedure - the download button will instruct the portal to execute queries to the select services and layers in order to acquire the correspondent soil data(sets), if data is available for the selected area (spatial filter).

The portal will popup the number of result windows according to the number of selected layers. In each window it will be displayed the output of the query to the layer, which can be one of the following:
1. A message informing that no data as found.
2. A message informing that the data found is too big.
3. A download link to the data found.
4. A download link to the data found and a tabular display of that data (example below)

The reasoning of the previous types of responses is as follows:
1. The select spatial filter didn't intersect any data on the selected layer(s), i.e. the spatial extend of the layer wasn't intersected by the user spatial filter bounding box rectangle. Therefore no data can be returned.
2. There is a limit of 16MB for the amount of soil data returned for each layer. If this limit is crossed no data is returned and the user should narrow the spatial filter.
3. Another limitation is applied to the size of the data returned and the possibility of being displayed in a tabular format. If the returned data size is greater than 8MB, only a download link shall be displayed allowing, at least, the data to be downloaded by the user.
4. When the returned data size is less or equal to 8MB the portal can display it in a tabular format - all columns and rows of information - along with the download link for the user to copy the data into his computer.

p.u: Step 8 : continue work with the portal

content.p: After the last step above, the user may wish to execute other queries to the same or other layers or eventually use other functionalities of the GS Soil Portal.

He should close the output popup windows (with the results) and proceed from step 1; or just redo the spatial index and then proceed from step 5; or select other services and layers and then proceed from step 2 or finally select other functionality from the portal.

If you have registered with your account under ‚MyGS Soil’, you can save your settings under ‚Active Services’. Therefor klick on the Link ‚Save map’ above the legend. Below the map viewer appeares a dialogue field, which offers the possibility to save the construction under a user-definded name. After saving a definite URL is assigned, which is continued to use.
Via the toolbar you can carry out different actions directly or by clicking in the map.
You can add any GetCapabilities-URL (external service) by using this button. With the ‚Add WMSs’ button the service is added to the active services and shown in map viewer.
In doing this you can select (check box) whether the layer of the service is directly activated and whether the service's map section is to be directly zoomed in on.

The information query in the map is directly activated via this button. The Informations were requested via a OGC WMS getFeature-Request to the integrated WMS service. By clicking once in the map you receive information specific to the location in the layer shown.
Which information is displayed depends on which layer under ‚Active Services’ has the check box (infoquery in map) activated (see above). At present not all services support this function.

Point coordinates can be called up in the map by this button. The position of the mouse is displayed in geographic coordinates underneath the map. The coordinates of the last click in the map are also displayed.

You can zoom into the map with one click on this button. You can bring up any map section by drawing up a square whilst holding down the left mouse button. The map is centred on this section and correspondingly enlarged.
The map is reduced in size by half with one click on this button.

With this button the map can be dragged. To drag: click with the left mouse button on a point in the map, hold the button down and pull the mouse over the map. After the operation the point on the map clicked on will then to be found at the position where you release the button.
By clicking on this button the map section displayed before the last action will be restored.
The action can be performed several times one after the other.
If you have gone back to a map section via the ‚Back’ button, which is one or several actions back, you can ‚leaf forward’ to the actions performed after that by means of the ‚forward’ button
The action can be performed as many times as the ‚Back’ action was executed previously.
By clicking on this button the zoom is restored to the start extend of the map.

By means of this button a PDF-document of the map is produced with or without a key. You can select the orientation of the map and in addition insert a title and commentary. You can print or save the document via the usual PDF functions.

With this button a map section (bounding box) can be selected. After activating the button you can click on a point in the map and, by holding down left mouse button draw up a rectangle. After then letting go of the button the coordinates of the bounding box are displayed underneath the map.

Under News listed current releases on the subject of the ‚soil’ from the project. Here the latest report is always on top. Each time only the title and a short description of the report are displayed. By clicking on the report you will be taken to the original report.
Older reports, which are no longer displayed on the home page, are stored in the report archive. You can look at these reports by clicking on the ‚Additional News ’ link.
GS Soil Portal offers you the possibility of putting your own settings in place on lasting basis. Using these you can:

ul.li: Adapt the home page to your requirements

content.p: To do this you must register and receive a user name and a password. Registration is free. Your details will not be passed on and are only used in anonymised form for statistical purposes.
If you already have a user name and a password you can enter them here and click on ‚Sign-on’.
If you do not yet have a user name and password then click on the ‚New User’ link. This will take you to the ‚Login’ form.
Please fill out the form. The detail fields with a star * are mandatory and must be filled in. All other details are voluntary.
All details are handled in strict confidence and are only used for anonymised statistical evaluation.

If you have forgotten your password, click on the ‚Password forgotten?’ link. You will then be taken to the corresponding form in which you can enter your e-mail address. After submitting you will be sent your user name and password by return.

If you would always like to use your personl settings you can select the ‚automatic login’ option. Then you will not have to enter your username and password every time to access the site. (Note: this operation functions only if you have given your internet browser permission to use cookies).

section.header: Your personal GS Soil Portal home page

content.p: This link leads you to your personal home page as set up by you in the personalisation function.
This link takes you to the form with your details thus far. If your details have changed, this is where you can update with these changes.
The data fields with a star * are mandatory and have to be filled in. All other details are voluntary.
All details are handled in strict confidence and are only used for anonymised statistical evaluation.
You can set the following settings according to your wishes.

section.header: Personalisation of the GS Soil Portal Main Page

content.p: In this area you can set which contents are to be displayed in which order on your personal home page. For this you set the contents of lines 1 to 3 in the main column (on the left) of the home page via the dropdown list. If you do not set your contents at all (empty entry in the dropdown list) this is also not displayed.
You can follow the same procedure for the margin column (narrower margin on the right side) of the home page.
The determinations are not saved permanently as presetting. After klick on LOGOUT you return to the home page of GS Soil Portal with its own presettings.

section.header: Filter by Countries or Data Providers

content.p: In this area you can regulate whether the information displayed for you is to be restricted to only a country (e.g. Portugal) and/or to individual data providers (e.g. Portugal and INRB).
The settings relate to the search as well as to the publication areas.

The settings are saved permanently as preset settings. However, you can overwrite them again temporarily via the settings possibilities in the abovementioned areas (thus, for example, for individual searches).

section.header: Filter by Types and Data Sources

content.p: As well as the usual web servers, metadata and specialist data systems are also connected to GS Soil Portal. You can now select whether you want to search in all data sources (standard) or whether you would like to restrict your search in a targeted manner to one or several types of data sources.
If you limit yourself to metadata then you will continue to have the possibility of selecting the classes of metadata you would like to search. The following classes are available to you:
The settings made will be effective on a lasting basis as preset settings. You can however overwrite them via temporary settings for individual searches.

section.header: Sorting and grouping of search results

content.p: You can display your search results either according to ranking (relevance of the page found with regard to your search term) or according to actuality (the latest pages are shown first).

Grouping means that all search results of a page are collected in groups. Depending on the setting, all the search results for countries or provider are collected together or those of all providers or domains.

p.b: Include similar terms in the search

content.p: GS Soil Portal not only performs the usual indexing of the pages found on search engines but gets the page contents analysed by the semantic service. As a result of this analysis, appropriate technical terms from the Thesaurus are assigned to the web pages.

If you select the setting Include similar terms in search then these keywords will be taken account of in the search. (Note: one should assume that selecting this setting increases the number of hits.)
The settings will be effective on a lasting basis as preset settings for the display of the search result list, but can be overwritten via Settings in Search for individual searches.
You leave the personalised area via LOGOUT and return to the home page of GS Soil Portal with its standard preset settings.
